title: Expenses and benefits: cash sum payments to employees

details.description: Tax and reporting rules for employers who meet or reimburse an employee's expenses - scale rate payments round sum allowances (RSA)
details.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for personal and business expenses

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
As an employer providing business or private expenses for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

There are separate rules for individual benefits you provide to your employees. You need to follow specific reporting and payment rules for different items, including travel, meals and accommodation.

What’s included

The rules on cash sum payments for business expenses cover:

  • cash sums you provide to meet the costs of your employees’ expenses
  • expenses they’ve paid for themselves that you reimburse
  • ‘scale rate payments’ you pay at a level agreed with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
  • ‘round sum allowances’, which you give to an employee regardless of how they spend them

Payments for private expenses count as earnings.

parts.title: Rules for business expenses
parts.body:
In general, something only counts as a business expense if your employee needs it to do their job. You don’t have to deduct or pay tax and National Insurance on qualifying business expenses, but you need to make sure that they meet all of HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC’s) criteria for:

  • employees’ business expenses (tax)

  • employees’ business expenses (National Insurance)

Business travel

Costs relating to business travel also count as business expenses, unless the travel is in the employee’s own vehicle.

For more details, see the guides on:

  • travel expenses
  • business travel mileage for employees’ own vehicles

What to report and pay

You don’t need to report or pay anything if you provide business expenses for employees earning at a rate of less than £8,500 a year.

For employees earning at a rate of more than £8,500 a year:

  • you’ll need to report the cost of the expenses on form P11D, section N, unless you have a dispensation covering them
  • you don’t need to deduct or pay any tax or National Insurance

You can apply for a dispensation to cover some business expenses. This means you won’t have to include them in your end-of-year reports.

parts.title: Rules for private expenses
parts.body:
Private expenses are anything that doesn’t count as a business expense, eg the cost of any travel that isn’t necessary for your employee to do their job.

If you cover the costs of private expenses, this counts as earnings. You’ll need to:

  • add the amount to your employee’s other earnings
  • deduct and pay Pay As You Earn (PAYE) tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

parts.title: Scale rate payments
parts.body:
If you provide your employees with a set amount of cash for some common business expenses like travel and meals, these are known as ‘scale rate payments’.

As long as your employee has actually spent the scale rate payment on business expenses, you won’t need to check every single receipt – it’s fine to just check a sample.

You can set up a scale rate payment by either:

  • agreeing a scale rate with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) by providing evidence of typical expenses (eg receipts)
  • using HMRC’s benchmark scale rates for subsistence costs

HMRC also provides benchmark rates for employees travelling outside of the UK.

What to report and pay

You don’t need to report or pay anything if you provide scale rate payments for employees earning at a rate of less than £8,500 a year.

For employees earning at a rate of £8,500 or more a year:

  • you’ll need to report scale rate payments on form P11D, section N unless you have a dispensation covering them
  • you don’t need to deduct or pay any tax or National Insurance

You can apply for a dispensation to cover scale rate payments. This means you won’t have to include them in your end-of-year reports.

parts.title: Round sum allowances
parts.body:
If you provide a set amount of cash for employees regardless of how they spend it, this is known as a ‘round sum allowance’.

This counts as earnings, so you’ll need to:

  • add the full amount of the round sum allowance to the employee’s other earnings when deducting and paying Pay As You Earn (PAYE) tax through payroll
  • add the amount of the round sum allowance – minus any specific business expenses covered by it – to the employee’s other earnings when deducting and paying Class 1 National Insurance through payroll
